title: 111_hr2906
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Problem Gambling Act of 2009" and includes findings related to problem gambling. Congress finds that problem gambling is a public health disorder with serious consequences, affecting over 6 million adults last year. The social cost of problem gambling was $6.7 billion, leading to bankruptcy, divorce, job loss, and criminal justice costs. Problem gambling is linked to higher rates of bankruptcy, domestic abuse, suicide, substance abuse, and mental health disorders. Many States are expanding legal gambling to raise revenues due to budget shortfalls. SAMHSA is the lead Federal agency for substance abuse and mental health services, while there is no formal responsibility for problem gambling in the Federal Government. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs for problem and pathological gambling. This is in response to the expansion of legal gambling in many states to raise revenues. SAMHSA is the lead Federal agency for substance abuse and mental health services, with no formal responsibility for problem gambling in the Federal Government. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a national campaign to increase awareness of problem gambling issues. This includes supporting existing campaigns and creating public service announcements. Additionally, the Secretary will coordinate voluntary donations to fund new programs and enhance existing campaigns through various media channels. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a national campaign to increase awareness of problem gambling issues, targeting radio and television audiences of sporting and gambling events. The campaign aims to prevent problem gambling through media outlets and evaluate its effectiveness, with an authorized appropriation of $200,000. Authorized appropriation of $200,000 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014. SEC. 5. RESEARCH. The President will establish a national research program on problem gambling, appointing an advisory commission to coordinate federal agencies' activities. Recommendations from the National Gambling Impact Study Commission report will be considered. Authorization of appropriations will be provided for this purpose. Authorization of $4,000,000 for fiscal years 2010 through 2014 is provided for a national research program on problem gambling. SEC. 6. TREATMENT. The Secretary may provide grants to States, local, and tribal governments, and nonprofit agencies for comprehensive services related to problem gambling treatment and prevention, as well as education. Applications for grants must be submitted to the Secretary with necessary information. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014 for this purpose. The President will develop a treatment improvement protocol specific to problem gambling, with $10,000,000 allocated for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2014. Congress believes that each state should allocate a portion of its gambling revenue towards addressing problem gambling through prevention, treatment, research, and education services.
